questions.question: Question 1: Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called
questions.explanation:
Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called receptive field. Sensory Unit: A single afferent neuron with all its receptor endings. Motor unit: Each single motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates. Dermatome: Each spinal nerve innervates a “segmental field” of the skin. 216 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: Fast vibration sense is mediated by  
.
questions.explanation:
Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles. Pacinian corpuscle is the most sensitive mechanoreceptor in the somatosensory system. It is 
responsive to high-frequency (30–500 Hz) vibratory stimuli and pressure. They are rapidly 
adapting receptors. Option A: Merkel's disc sense touch and sustained pressure. They are slow adapting receptors. 
Present in epidermis. Option B: Meissner's corpuscle sense tap and flutter. They are present in dermal papillae. They 
are rapidly adapting receptors. Option D: Ruffini endings sense skin stretch and fluttering vibration. The following image shows Merkel's disc and Meissner's corpuscle being more superficial 
(reponsive to touch) than Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscle (which are deeper in the dermis 
and responsive to pressure).

questions.question: Question 3: The phasic receptor is
questions.explanation: Meissner's corpuscles are phasic (rapidly adapting) receptors. Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, and muscle spindle are tonic (slowly adapting) receptors.

questions.question:
Question 4: You are doing a CNS examination of a patient with a spinal injury. At which of the following 
sites would the distance of two-point discrimination be greatest?
questions.explanation:
The distance of two-point discrimination is greatest at the back of the scapula. 217 
Sold by @itachibot The relative tactile acuity of a given region can be determined by the two-point discrimination 
test. Here, calipers are used to determine the minimum distance between the two points which 
can be perceived as two points. Greater the density of receptors  Smaller the receptive field  
More precise the localization. For e.g., Stimulus points on the back, for instance, must be separated by at least 65 mm before 
they can be distinguished as separate, whereas on the fingertips two stimuli are recognized if they 
are separated by as little as 2 mm. The lips have the greatest acuity (two-point discrimination 
threshold ~ 1 mm). Clinical significance: Blind individuals benefit from the tactile acuity of fingertips to facilitate the ability to read 
Braille. The dots forming Braille symbols are separated by 2.5 mm. Two-point discrimination is used to test the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus) 
system.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is true about the nature of the sensory receptor given below:
questions.explanation:
The sensory receptor shown in the above image is Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is a 
rapidly adapting receptor and is an encapsulated receptor. When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequency 
of the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is known 
as receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidly 
or slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow adapting receptors (tonic).

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following classification of receptors is the same?
questions.explanation:
Mechanoreceptors and exteroceptors have the same classification of receptors. Exteroceptors are concerned with the external environment or receptors which receives external 
stimuli. Mechanoreceptors are cutaneous receptors for touch and pressure. Thus 
mechanoreceptors can be considered to be exteroceptors. Nociceptors are pain receptors which detect physical and chemical damage occuring in the tissue. Interoceptors are concerned with the internal environment. Chemoreceptors are receptors stimulated by a change in the chemical composition of the 
environment in which they are located. These include receptors for taste and smell as well as 
visceral receptors such as those sensitive to changes in the plasma level of O2, pH, and osmolality. Teleceptors (distance receivers) are concerned with events at a distance, example - 
photoreceptors. Proprioceptors provide information about the position of the body in space at any given instant. 218 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following is true regarding sensory receptor properties? 211 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the intensity of the stimulus
options.b: A touch receptor will generate a constant rate of discharge of its axon for as long as the
options.c: Meissner’s and Pacinian corpuscles adapt slowly, the others adapt rapidly
options.d: The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the

questions.explanation:
The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the 
stimulus given to its receptor. Intensity of stimulus applied to a sensory receptor can be determined by the following: • Variation in frequency of action potentials generated • Variations in the number of receptors activated Option A : Weber-Fechner Law states that magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to 
the log of the intensity of the stimulus. Option B: A touch receptor will not generate a constant rate of discharge, even if the receptor is 
continuously stimulated. This is called desensitization or adaptation. If the opposite were true (if 
option B was correct), when we have our clothes on, we would have constant firing of neurons 
unnecessarily, in response to touch stimulus. Option C: Rapidlyadapting(Phasic rece 
ptors) Slowadapting(Tonic receptor

questions.question:
Question 8: A fibers do not transmit  
.
questions.explanation:
A fibers do not transmit slow pain. They transmit fast pain. Activation of A fibers, which release glutamate, is responsible for first pain (also called fast pain 
or epicritic pain), which is a rapid response and mediates the ability to localize the site and 
intensity of the noxious stimulus. Neuropathic pain can also be burning, dull and poorly localized (protopathic pain, transmitted by 
C nociceptor fibers (which release substance P). Dual Pain Pathway Pain can be carried by either A fiber (fast pain/ epicritic pain) or by C fiber (slow pain/protopathic 
pain) Feature

questions.question:
Question 9: The most potent algogenic substance is  
.
questions.explanation:
Bradykinin is the most potent algogenic substance. An algogenic substance is a chemical released at the site of injury which mediates pain. These 
include bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolytic 
enzymes. Prostaglandins and substance P enhance the sensitivity of pain endings but do not directly excite 
them. Note: This is a controversial question According to Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page 622- "One chemical that seems to be more painful than others is bradykinin. Researchers have 
suggested that bradykinin might be the agent most responsible for causing pain after tissue 
damage." Hence, bradykinin is the better answer (not serotonin)

questions.question:
Question 10: Vanilloid receptors are activated by all except  
.
questions.explanation:
Vanilloid receptors are not activated by vibration. Vanilloid receptors or TRPV1 (transient receptor potential vanilloid1) receptors are a part 
of family of nonselective cation channels called transient receptor potential (TRP) channels. These 
channels respond to intense heat, acids, and chemicals such as capsaicin.

questions.question:
Question 12: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to  
.
questions.explanation:
Weber-Fechner Law states that the magnitude of sensation felt is proportionate to the log of the 
intensity of the stimulus. Other Laws in Physiology: • Doctrine of specific nerve energies - When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are 
stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized no matter how or 
where along the pathway the activity is initiated. • Law of projection - No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course 
to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor. This 
principle is called the law of projection.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient's right leg was amputated because it was unsalvageable after the motor vehicle 
accident. After 2 weeks of her surgery, she started feeling episodes of severe pain in the 
amputated area. This pain is most likely based on which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation:
This patient is having phantom limb pain. This pain is based on cortical plasticity. Cortical structures are capable of reorganization after the loss of a body part. The cortical 
representation of the neighboring parts spreads into the cortical area that was formerly occupied 
by the representation of the amputated part. This is called cortical plasticity leads to the 
phenomenon of phantom limb pain

questions.question: Question 14: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is
questions.explanation:
Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is allodynia. Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus. An example of primary 
hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of the 
skin pain endings by local tissue products released due to burns — histamine, prostaglandins, and 
others. Causalgia is a type of neuropathic pain.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is true about anandamide? 213 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray

questions.explanation:
There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray and other areas concerned 
with pain. There are 2 types of endogenous cannabinoids: 2-arachidonyl glycerol and Anandamide. They 
bind to CB1 and CB2 receptors. They have an anti-nociceptive effect. 221 
Sold by @itachibot Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray inhibit transmission in 
nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla 
(Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases 
endogenous opiates.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is true about visceral pain?

options.c: It is mediated by B fibers

questions.explanation:
Visceral pain is poorly localized, unpleasant and associated with nausea and autonomic 
symptoms. It often originates from thoracic and abdominal cavities, transmitted through small 
type C pain fibers. It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic 
and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal 
horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex. When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic 
segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is 
called the dermatomal rule. Example: the heart and the arm have the same segmental origin. Feature 
Afiber

questions.question:
Question 17: Pain insensitive structure is  
.
questions.explanation:
Alveoli are pain insensitive structures. Alveoli of lungs and parenchyma of liver are almost 
completely insensitive to the pain of any type. However, the liver capsule is extremely sensitive to both direct trauma and stretch. The bile ducts, 
arterial walls, bronchi and the parietal pleura are very sensitive to pain.

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient with chronic pain is undergoing transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation for pain 
relief. What is the basis of this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) of pain relief is based on the gate theory of 
pain. This method uses electrodes to activate A and A fibers near the injury to relieve pain. Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. 222 
Sold by @itachibot The relief may result from inhibition of pain pathways (Inhibition of C fibers and A-delta fibers) in 
the dorsal horn gate, by stimulation of large-diameter touch-pressure afferents(A-beta fibers). This 
is called the gate-control hypothesis. Interesting clinical application: Touching or shaking an injured area decreases the pain due to the 
injury. Stimulation with an electric vibrator at the site of pain also gives some relief. The same mechanism is probably responsible for the efficacy of counterirritants. Stimulation of 
the skin over an area of visceral inflammation produces some relief of the pain due to the visceral 
disease. The old-fashioned mustard plaster works on this principle.

questions.question:
Question 20: The transient receptor potential (TRP) channel that is most active at normal skin temperature 
is  
.
questions.explanation:
At normal skin temperatures, TRPV3 is the most active receptor. 223 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, 
how do you best measure his temperature?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the core 
body temperature. During low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly 
misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperatures Infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representative 
of core body temperature. However, more often the thermometer is not inserted adequately or for 
safety reasons, they are manufactured in such a way that they do not reach deep into the ear 
canal, or the ear canal contains cerumen which can disturb the measurement. Hence the infrared 
thermometer more commonly delivers the temperature of ear canal cerumen and hence not a 
reliable method of measuring the core body temperature. 224 
Sold by @itachibot Somatosensory Pathways
